ETYMOLOGY: From Old French mortel, from Latin mortalis 'subject to death', from mors, mort- 'death'.

MEANINGS.POS_TIP: adjective: a word that describes or modifies a noun or pronoun
MEANINGS.DEF_EN: Subject to death; unable to live forever.

MEANINGS.POS_TIP: adjective: a word that describes or modifies a noun or pronoun
MEANINGS.DEF_EN: Causing or able to cause death; fatal.
MEANINGS.SENT_EN: He suffered a mortal wound in the battle.
MEANINGS.SENT_ZH: 他在战斗中受了致命伤。

MEANINGS.POS_TIP: adjective: a word that describes or modifies a noun or pronoun
MEANINGS.DEF_EN: (Of a feeling, struggle, or enemy) intense, extreme, or irreconcilable.
MEANINGS.DEF_ZH: （指感情、斗争或敌人）强烈的，极度的，不共戴天的。
MEANINGS.SENT_EN: She was in mortal fear of losing her job.

MEANINGS.POS_TIP: noun: a word (other than a pronoun) used to identify any of a class of people, places, or things (common noun), or to name a particular one of these (proper noun)
MEANINGS.DEF_EN: A human being, as distinguished from a god or immortal being.
MEANINGS.DEF_ZH: 凡人；人类（区别于神或不朽者）。
MEANINGS.SENT_EN: Even mortals can achieve great things.
MEANINGS.SENT_ZH: 即使是凡人也能成就伟大的事业。
